Kuraray America -Septon's environmental health and safety program includes policies, procedures, standards and guidance documents designed to fulfill septon's commitment to the environment, safety and health of our employees and neighbors.  These materials include  Risk Management Program (RMP) guidance to help our facility prevent and/or reduce the risk of accidents.  

This Risk Mangement Plan summarizes the management, administrative, procedural, and technological controls that, when integrated, minimize public risk of hazardous chemical release exposure.  The plan summary is organized to correspond with the specific EPA RMP definitions and requirements. 

Overall responsigility for all facility activities including Risk Management activities, lie with the Plant Manager.  The Plant Manager has delegated the following responsibilities:

1.  RMP hazard assessment and document control to the Environmental Manager

2.  Implementation of the RMP to the Operations Manager

3.  Development and maintenance of the RMP Emergency Response Program to the Safety Engineer

4.  Training and  ommunication of RMP related manners to the Operations Manager

More specific responsibilities are delegated to other staff positions as detailed in the Plant Emergency Response Plan.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Septon is committed to conduct its operations in a safe, responsible manner and reducing risks to health and the environment.  Compliance with all applicable legal requirements is mandatory and considered essential to upholding the company's commitment.  Septon's Environmental, Health and Safety programs include policies, procedures, standards and guidance materials designed to minimize the potential for an accidental release.  



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Septon, located in Pasadena, Texas, manufactures styrene thermoplastic elastomers in a batch polymerization process.  The product is used in the production

of consumer goods such as pen grips, tool grips, automotive parts and plastic modification.

Two RMP regulated substances are present on site at the Septon facility.  The substances are 1,3 butadiene and isoprene, both are classified as flammable materials in the RMP rule.  The chemicals are raw materils for the manufacturing of thermoplastic elastomers.  



Accidental Release Prevention Program

In general, Septon has implemented numerous steps to minimize the potential release of any chemical on site.  All storage tanks are located within dike areas; truck unloading facilities are equipped with low pressure alarms, automated shut-off valves, sprinkler systems and are located within dike areas.  Butadiene storage is equipped with a water deluge system.  Isoprene storage is equipped with a foam injection system.  All of the process areas at the facility subject to the EPA Risk Management Program regulation are also subject ot the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard.  Process containing 1, 3 butadiene and/or isoprene that are subject ot the EPA RMP rule have been incorporated into the OSHA PSM Program.  Thus a program is in place that is in compliance withboth the OSHA and RMP regulations.  Specific elements of the program include the following:

*Employee participation in process safety management aand accident prevention

*Process Safety Information

*Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

*Dcoumented Operating Procedures

*Training Programs for all employees

*Contractor Requirements and Training

*Pre-startup Reviews

*Mechanical Integrity Program

*Quality Assurance Program

*Management of Change Process

*Incident Investigation

*Compliance Audits

*Safe Work Practices



Prevention steps for the Worst Case Scenario consist of preventive tank maintenance, inspection and safe work practices.  The 1, 3 butadiene tank is located in a secure dike area.  There are no flammable substances stored within the dike area.  In the unlikely event of a tank rupture, the

dike surrounding the tank wil minimize the spread of the 1, 3 butadiene and significantly reduce the impact of the spill.



Prevention steps for the Alternate Case Scenario consist of remote control shutoff valves located at each end of the truck.  Additionally, the off loading line can be shutdown downstream of the unloading site.  Operators are trained according to a coumented procedure for the unloading of butadiene.   Personal protective equipment is located at the unloading area to assure quick response to any potential spill.  Gas detectors are located in the area along with a deluge system to help prevent chance of fire.



Five Year History



On Sept 16, 2010 gas detector alarm sounded in control room and it was determined that BPV-1101(Backpressure valve) was leaking ,BD and IP (Butadiene and Isoprene). System was isolated,depressured and cleared. It was determined that the cause of the release was due to overpressurization due to thermal expansion. The process system design was revised to include equipment to mitigate overpressurization due to thermal expansion.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Chemical safety is a part of the working culture at the Septon facility.  Reducing employees' and the general public's risk to chemical exposure is an ongoing effort.  Septon resolves all findings from Process Hazard Analyses, internal and external audits some of which result in process modifications.
